More info: The Amṛtataraṅgiṇī is the title of Lakṣmīdhara's commentary on the Bhāgavata Purāṇa. Although a close contemporary of Śrīdhara Svāmin, and likely also a native of Orissa, Lakṣmīdhara appears to betray no awareness of this other, more famous commentator on the text. Moreover, extant manuscripts of the Amṛtataraṅgiṇī are mostly found in Kerala, as is its intellectual legacy. It influences the Kṛṣnapadī by Rāghavānanda, a Śaiva author of several commentaries on stotras and other devotional texts.

More info:
The Ānandasundarī is a saṭṭaka in four acts. Like all saṭṭakas, the predominant language of the play is Prakrit. The author, Ghanaśyāma, says that he composed it when he was 22 years old.

The main character is the king Śikhaṇḍacandra. He marries the princess Ānandasundarī, the daughter of king Caṇḍavega of the Aṅgas.

The play contains two garbha-nāṭakas, one in the first act, and one in the fourth.

Manuscript distribution: Only in Kerala.
More info:
​The Āścaryacūḍāmaṇi is a play (nāṭaka) in seven acts that focuses on a number of episodes from the Rāmāyaṇa, from the Araṇyakāṇḍa onwards.

According to the prologue (sthāpanā), the play has come "from the Deccan" (dakṣiṇāpathād āgatam), and the actress' incredulity at this remark has suggested to several scholars that the Āścaryacūḍāmaṇi was the earliest Sanskrit play, or at least the earliest nāṭaka, to be composed in South India. What seems more likely is that the Āścaryacūḍāmaṇi predates the plays of Kulaśekhara (ca. 10th century).

The seven acts of the Āścaryacūḍāmaṇi are in the repertoire of Kūṭiyāṭṭam performers in Kerala. Old Kramadīpikās (director's manuals) and Āṭṭaprakārams (actor's manuals) are available for most of the acts.

More info:
The Caṇḍānurañjana is a prahasana (satire) of Ghanaśyāma that is not yet published. Chitra Shukla describes it as follows:

"Three young men---Mārjāra, Barkara, and Tarṇaka---are allowed by a Dīkṣita to have free sexual relations with his wife Sthūlayoni. The Dīkṣita himself wants to make love to another lady. Barkata proposes to dress Tarṇaka as a lady and to send to the Dīkṣita. The Prahasana thus contains various rather disconnected scenes within this thin outline. Thus the three young men meet a Digambara monk who was caught red-handed when he was making love to a wealthy housewife. They also meet the Physician Vakradanta, the poet Tātajata, Dīrghaśefa, and Sārameya."

"The Prahasana freely refers to homosexuality, masturbation, illicit love and contains highly improper descriptions of women. The corrupt ways and behaviour of the ascetics are satirized and ridiculed. The Prahasana has become a curious mixture of course, farcical buffoonery, and intellectual laughter. The humour springs from witty and striking dialogues, jokes, and sarcastic references to Physicians, Goswamis and monks of ದther sects."

More info: Nāgavarman’s Chandōmbudhi, the earliest surviving work on meter in Kannada (and one of the earliest Kannada texts to survive at all) was probably composed around 990 CE, when Nāgavarman was affiliated with the court of the Ganga king Rakkasa.

Manuscript distribution: This is one of the works on a palm-leaf manuscript, dated to 1190 saṃvat (1124 CE), preserved in a jñāna-bhaṇḍār in Jaisalmer, Rajasthan.
More info: The Chandonuśāsana is an important work of metrics (chandaḥśāstra). In addition to defining all of the standard Sanskrit verse forms, it also contains definitions of Sanskrit verse forms only used in the Deccan (such as mattebhavikrīḍita), as well as verse forms that are primarily used in Prakrit (like the galitakas) and Kannada (like the tripadī and akṣara).

The Ḍamaruka is a series of ten conversations, called Alaṅkāras, on various themes:


	Rājānurañjanam: A praise of the king.
	Kalidūṣaṇam: The evils of the Kali age.
	Sukavisañjīvanam: On good poets.
	Kukavisantāpanam: On bad poets.
	Abodhākaram: Difficult-to-understand poetry.
	Śābdikabhañjanam: Grammatical errors.
	Paṇḍitakhaṇḍanam.
	Jātisantarjanam.
	Prabhutvam: On the qualities of rulers.
	Akhaṇḍānandam: On Brahman.

Structure: The work follows a simple flow of verses and is not divided into formal sections.
More info: The Durgacandrakalastuti is a very brief work consisting of sixteen verses, all of which are in the vasantatilaka meter.  There are also two framing stanza, one at the beginning and one at the end, both in the anustubh meter. Brevity is paired with simplicity in this work. The verses are in easy Sanskrit, with no unusual grammatical forms or syntactic constructions. The work is very straightforward and lacks complex figuration. Appayya Diksita, the scholar who had such a profound impact on the alamkara discourse in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries has, by and large, refrained here from the use of ornaments of speech. The work is accompanied by an autocommentary that explains its plan: the first 8 or so verses sum up the Devīmāhātmya, and the remaining verses sum events from other sources on the goddess. the Varāhapurāṇa (verses 9–11), the Harivamśa (12–14), and the Bhāgavata (15–16), before concluding with a verse alluding to the relevant portion of a Vedic text, the Samavidhibrahmana (17). This design follows the expressed intention of showing that the Goddess won the praise of the trinity of Brahma (in the Devīmāhātmya), Śiva (in the Varāhapurāṇa), and Viṣṇu (in the Harivaṃśa and the Bhāgavata).

More info: Kuṇacākarar mentions a work called the Guṇagāṅkīyaṃ in his commentary to the first kārikai of Amitacākarar's Yāpparuṅkalakkārikai. He notes two points of similarity between Amitacākarar's work and "a work on Kannada meter calls Guṇagāṅkīyaṁ (kuṇakāṅkiyam eṉṉum karunāṭakac cantam-e). One is that both works contain a second-person address to a woman (makaṭūu-muṉṉilai). The other is that both involve a "submission to the assembly" (avai-y-aṭakkam). Since the work is named for the Eastern Cāḷukya ruler Guṇagāṅka (Vijayāditya III), who ruled roughly from 843 to 887, the work is the earliest text on Kannada meter known to us, and roughly contemporary with Śrīvijaya's Kavirājamārgaṁ, associated with the court of the Rāṣṭrakūṭa king Amōghavarṣa (the Rāṣṭrakūṭas being the traditional enemies of the Eastern Cāḷukyas).

Manuscript distribution: One manuscript from Jaisalmer, Rajasthan, dated to saṃvat 1190 (1124 CE), containing Jayadeva’s chandas and Harṣaṭa’s commentary on it.
More info: Jayadeva’s Chandas is one of the earliest surviving works of metrics (chandaḥśāstra), after Piṅgala’s Sūtras and the treatment of meters in the Nāṭyaśāstra. It adopts Piṅgala’s technical terminology, but uses a novel mode of definition, where the metrical forms are both defined and exemplified in a single pāda of the meter in question. The text was widely studied, especially among Jains.

Manuscript distribution: One manuscript of the Jayadevacchandas with Harṣaṭa’s commentary is available from the collections in Jaisalmere, Rajasthan; it is dated to 1190 saṃvat (1124 CE).

More info: A standard text on the Alaṃkāraśāstra which teaches arthālaṃkāra. All the old treatises on the subject have been analysed and re-edited by the author, and the entire work was written in a very pleasing and clear manner with the help of examples and introducing some new alankaras also. Students of alaṃkāra generally read the Kuvalayānanda as the first standard work.

More info:
The Madanasaṃjīvana is a one-act play (bhāṇa) by Ghanaśyāma. According to Chitra Shukla:

"The hero of the Bhāṇa is a viṭa named Kulabhūṣaṇa, who loves Citralekhā. He goes out to meet her. On his way, he meets a Vedic scholar, a group of Vaiṣṇava ladies and widows, ladies from Gujarat, Andhra, and Maharashtra, a Mādhva preceptor, and Goswamis. He witnesses a street of Prostitutes and the love scenes in different places. He stops to witness a wrestling match, cock-fight, ramfight and meets his beloved in the end."

The play takes placed in Cidambaram.

More info: The anonymous commentator on the Nītivākyāmṛta says that Somadeva wrote it for a king Mahendrapāla. It would have to be Mahendrapāla II of Kannauj (mentioned in an inscription of Partapgarh of 946), but scholars are not certain about the attribution. Botto, following Raghavan, thinks that it is perfectly likely, given the political conditions of the time, that a poet could have moved from the court of the Pratihāras in Kannauj to the court of the Vēmulavāḍa Cāḷukyas; Handiqui thinks that there is no reason to believe that Somadeva ever lived in Kannauj.

Manuscript distribution: A single palm-leaf manuscript from Patan is available, with writing that dates it to around the 14th century. Many folios are missing. See Chheda’s edition for details.
Mentioned person: Hemacandra, Bharata, Abhinavagupta, Mammaṭa, Ānandavardhana, Bhāmaha, Ramacandra, Kumārila, Kālidāsa
More info: The Padaprakāśa is Ājaḍa’s commentary on the Sarasvatīkaṇṭhābharaṇa, dating to the latter half of the 13th century. This work quotes from many sources, but above all the works of Hemacandra (Kāvyānuśāsana, Abhidhānacintāmaṇi, etc.). He also quotes in extenso from Namisādhu’s commentary to Rudraṭa’s Kāvyālaṅkāra. Chheda has also pointed to reworkings of discussions of Arjunavarmadeva (on the verses of Amaru), as well as some telling similarities between Ājaḍa’s and Ratneśvara’s commentaries in chapter 3, but did not pronounce upon who might have borrowed from whom.

More info: The Ṛṣabhapañcāśikā (“Fifty for Ṛṣabha”) is a praise of the first tīrthaṅkara of Jainism, Ṛṣabha, in fifty Prakrit gāthās. It was composed by the poet Dhanapāla, who was associated with the Paramāra court in the late 10th and early 11th centuries.

Composed on Thursday 16 August, 1827 (as stated: sake 1749 śrāvaṇa vadya 10 guruvāra).

In verse.

More info: The Ṣaḍbhāṣācandrikā is a work on Prakrit grammar by Lakṣmīdhara. It is a rearrangement for pedagogical purposes of the Vālmīkisūtra, that is, of the sūtras of Trivikramadeva's Prakrit grammar of the early thirteenth century.

In eighty-three chapters. A work on architecture that includes chapters on geography, the extent of the earth, the ages of men and gods, the classes of society, varieties of earth, measurements, town planning, site plans, arteries and veins in the body of the vastupurusa, the marmans, planning based on the vastupurusa, royal palaces, timber from forests, Indra's banner, names of kinds of towns, building open-sided halls, uneven ground, 72 types of three-room buildings, two-room buildings, one-room houses, doors and walls, enumeration of house types, astrological considerations, eight kinds of public hall, doors, pillars, etc., beds, chairs, etc., the king's home, machines (ch. 31), elephants, horses, private and public items in buildings, stone foundations, bali offerings, peg-and-string measurements, city locations for officials and castes, doorways, thrones, bricklaying, peace performances, evils of falling doorways, qualities of an architect, eight components of town planning, peace offerings for a collapsed city gate, altars, faults in house building, several chapters on temples and palaces, including orientation etc. of courtiers' quarters and airplanes and other palaces (ch. 59), thrones again, southern palaces and skyscrapers, yet more on palaces and temples, pavilions (ch. 66), painting (71), clay moddeling and stucco, turrets and spires, measurement etc. of statues and divine images, types of human (81), eleven sentiments of painting (82), and sixty-four hand movements (83).
External resources: Scan of Baroda 1966 revised edition (in one volume) (http://n2t.net/ark:/13960/t1xd67h0g)

More info: The Sarasvatīkaṇṭhābharaṇa is a work on poetics by King Bhojadeva of Dhārā. It is different from the same author's grammar, also called Sarasvatīkaṇṭhābharaṇa.
The Sarasvatīkaṇṭhābharaṇa, or Śabdānuśāsana, is a work of grammar by King Bhoja of Dhārā. It is distinct from the work of poetics called Sarasvatīkaṇṭhābharaṇa by the same author.

Manuscript distribution: Manuscripts of this text are only found in Kerala (4 in the Kerala University MSS. Library, and 1 in the GOML, copied from an original in the Malabar district).

More info: The Saubhāgyacandrātapa of Nīlakaṇṭha Dīkṣita, a manual for the daily ritual obligations of the Śrīvidyā initiates in the seventeenth-century Smārta-Śaiva community of Tamil Nadu. To our knowledge, the Saubhāgyacandrātapa survives only in a single Grantha script palm-leaf manuscript, now housed at the Oriental Research Institute at the University of Kerala, Kariavottom. The manuscript itself is incomplete, only the first two chapters (paricchedas) having come down to us today from a work that most likely comprised at least five chapters. Nīlakaṇṭḥa often acknowledges the authority of the Śivārcanacandrikā of Appayya, whom he describes as “our grandfather” (asmatpitāmahacaraṇāḥ), or rather uniquely, with the proud but affectionate “Our Dīkṣita” (asmaddīkṣitaḥ). In addition, the Saubhāgyacandrātapa is referred to by name in yet another Śrīvidyā manual composed by his younger brother Atirātra Yajvan, entitled the Śrīpadarthadīpikā or Śrīpadārthavyavasthā, which may now be lost, but had been recovered prior to 1942 by P. P. S. Sastri. Nīlakaṇṭha further informs us in his own paddhati that his elder brother, Āccān Dīkṣita, also authored such a text, entitled the Saubhāgyapaddhati, of which no trace has yet been found. While simultaneously presenting a digest of Śrīvidyā upāsanā suitable for an orthodox Brahminical Śaiva audience, the Saubhāgyacandrātapa undertakes the project of bridging the gap between the Śrīvidyā textual canon and the scriptural and ritual canons of the Sanskritic Śaiva Siddhānta tradition, a school of thought quite far removed from Śrīvidyā's earlier ritual and philosophical influences.

Scholarship (print and note): B.N.K.Sharma 1984, The editors of the Poornaprajna Research Institute 1967

More info: Commentary on PMS, but includes also floating verses and summary verses (saṅgrahaśloka) at the beginning and end of each book and at the end of each adhikaraṇa. All verses are ślokas apart from the first three and the last one of SM 1. The first three are an atiśakvarī, an ārya with an abnormal structure (cd-ab instead of the opposite) and a vasantatilakā respectively. The last one in SM 1 is again an atiśakvarī

The Śivārcanacandrikā is a paddhati that appears to provide an exoteric outline of Śaiva Siddhānta daily observances, ācāra, and pūjā rituals. The prose of the text is copied (or perhaps plagiarized) directly from the Kriyāsāra, a Pañcārādhya Vīraśaiva Vedānta work outlining a Śaktiviśiṣṭādvaita or Śivādvaita interpretation of the Brahmasūtras. Despite Appayya's interest in Śivādvaita, he fails to copy any portions of the Kriyāsāra that discuss Śivādvaita Vedānta.

Dhanapāla’s Śrīvīrastuti is a hymn to the tīrthaṅkara Mahāvīra in 30 Prakrit verses. Each verse uses the device of virodha- (or virodhābhāsa-), an “apparent contradiction” that must be resolved by reading the words of the verse in a different sense.

References from Potter: yAV843,893; VV72
This work is a stotra in 52 verses that describes Viṣṇu from foot to head. It is traditionally ascribed to Śaṅkara. Since it was commented on by Pūrṇasarasvatī, its terminus ante quem is around 1400.

Structure: 100 chapters, prose and verses at the end of each chapter. The initial chapter and the two concluding ones are in verses.
Manuscript distribution: No manuscripts in southern scripts, only manuscripts in Devanāgarī have been used for the editions.
Scholarship (print and note): Kane, P.V. 1975 ((see all volumes by Kane 1962--1975). Kane compares it to Manu and Yājñavalkya.)
More info:
Edited on the basis of five manuscripts by Jolly (1881), and on the basis of 12 manuscripts in the Adyar Library (1964, with commentary by Nandapaṇḍita). Translated by Julius Jolly in 1880.

A Vaiṣṇava dharmaśāstra. Patrick Olivelle writes that it was written between 7th and 10th AD, on the basis of iconographic description of images found in eight c. Kaśmīr. Terminus ante quem: it is quoted by Medhātithi (9th c.) in his commentary on the Mānavadharmaśāstra. See Patrick Olivelle, INDOLOGICA TAURINENSIA 33 (2007).

Jolly and Kane note that it depends on Manu.

Lingat mentions it, but derives his information from Kane 1962--1975.

More info: The Yāpparuṅkalakkārikai is a text on Tamil prosody and metrics. It is one of two works on the subject composed by Amitacākarar, the other one being Yāpparuṅkalam. According to Niklas (1993), the Yāpparuṅkalam was composed before the Yāpparuṅkalakkārikai. Both were written "between the second half of the 10th c. AD and the beginning of the 11th c. AD" (Niklas 1993: III).

Kuṇacākarar's Viruttiyurai on Amitacākarar's Yāpparuṅkalakkārikai is a commentary that contains an enormous amount of information about Tamil literature (as well as Prakrit and Kannada literature) that has been lost. It probably dates to the end of the 10th century.

The Yāpparuṅkalam is a text on Tamil prosody and metrics. It is one of two works on the subject composed by Amitacākarar, the other one being Yāpparuṅkalakkārikai. According to Niklas (1993), the Yāpparuṅkalam was composed before the Yāpparuṅkalakkārikai. Both were written "between the second half of the 10th c. AD and the beginning of the 11th c. AD" (Niklas 1993: III).
